lessons.displayAs: Silent Prefix Clusters kn-, gn-, wr- ...
instructions: This lesson has some tricky words that start with 'silent' letters like kn-, gn-, and wr-.

It is incorrect to say that these letters are silent, because letters are built up into spellings and those spellings are not silent.  The 'k' in 'knot' is not silent, but rather the 'kn' in 'knot' is pronounced 'n'.  This idea is explored in the 'Phonics' course.

lessons.instructions:
This section of lessons introduces syllable division. The first syllable rule we will learn is:
VCCV: Divide between the two middle consonants.


1. Find the vowels.
2. Count the consonants between the vowels.
3. If there are two consonants, divide between them*
4. Read each syllable separately.
5. Read the entire word.

*when the two middle consonants form a digraph (ch, sh, ck, th), keep the consonants together and divide after the digraph (tick/et, chick/en, etc).

fluency: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to keep it.
It's okay! Let's be friends.
Let's take a walk and we'll talk.
It's been a long day and I'm tired.
She's sad that you can't go home.
You'll have to tell her we'll be there soon.

games.thumb: Contractions Whack-a-Mole
Contractions Word Sort
Contractions Random Cards
Contractions Mastery Flip
<iframe src='https://wordwall.net/embed/51184ed55fb1437f867608614d28f650?themeId=1&templateId=36' width='500' height='380' frameborder='0' allowfullscreen></iframe>

lessons.note: Identify the SOUND and the SPELLING of the vowel in each word.

html: WHAT IS PHONICS?
We use about 40 sounds for speaking English. Since we only have 26 letters, we can't simply use a letter of the alphabet for each sound.
Here's a sound that you can't find in the alphabet: oy and it has two common spellings:
'Phonics' is about mapping sounds to spellings that represent those sounds.
Letters: There are 26 letters. Letters make spellings and spellings make sounds. We shouldn't say "this letter makes a sound", because only spellings make sounds.
Spellings: There are about 180 common spellings, and spellings make sounds. The simplest spellings have one letter like 'a' in a which makes the ah sound in 'cat'.
People get confused because the letter 'a' seems the same as the spelling a which makes the ah sound. But that doesn't work for the spelling oi which makes the oy in 'soil'.
Now can you explain why 'letters' and 'spellings' are not the same?
In this program we will show sounds like this: oi and spellings like this: oy and oi.
We simplify the colours when we show a word-drawing.  You are familiar with word-drawings if you have taken the Blending program.
Here is the PURPOSE of the 'PHONICS' program:
There are only a few sounds.
But probably more than you think.
You must be able to recognize them.

Sounds have multiple spellings, and many common words have uncommon spellings.  It is confusing, and we can't help that.  The purpose of this program is to visit the sounds and build awareness of them.

instructions.note: Identify the SOUND and the SPELLING of the vowel in each word.

lessons.note: Identify the part of the word that you can 'sing' with your mouth open.  It is the vowel.

html: There are five spellings that have a trailing 'e', and we link the spelling together with a red bar.
You have already mastered reading these spellings, .
It is NOT correct to say that 'e' is silent in 'gate' or 'note'.   Nor is it correct to say that 'e' in the
spelling a_e of 'gate' modifies the sound of the a.
The correct way to think is that the spelling a makes the sound ah

and the spelling a_e makes the sound ay.
For this program,
let's pretend that there are NO silent letters in English.  The 'k' in 'knife' is not silent, but rather the spelling
kn makes the sound n. You will see that this approach simplifies
English spelling and make it much more regular.
If you play with sounds for a few minutes, you will see that you can hold r,
class='sound'>wh,v and j. Those are sometimes called

semi-vowels and behave like vowels in many ways. Try them.
So again, how many vowels are there? We are going
to teach the 16 vowels across the top of this page, but there is no clear answer.  Depending on who is counting and why,
there are between 14 and 20 vowels in English, plus the semi-vowels.
The next tab of this lesson lists 16 vowels we will study in this program, with an example word below.
We would like you and your tutor to memorize the sounds of the vowels (don't bother remembering the

example words).
The sound ah makes an 'ahh' sound like 'cat'.

We want you to see ah and say 'ahh'.
You can practice them on tab 3
without the example words.  Then visit the Words page and make sure you know them.

fluency: Will you serve dinner to the next person?

My sister’s hamster ran under her bed.
